p: Strychnos icaja (Loganiaceae) is found all over Central Africa [ 74]. In Cameroon, for example, the roots are used by a Pygmy tribe to treat malaria. From their stem bark, six indole alkaloids ( 8 to 13) (Figs. 3 and 4), were isolated and evaluated against the CQ-sensitive 3D7 strain of P. falciparum by Tchinda et al. [ 61], with IC 50 values ranging from 0.40 to 110 μM. These include 15-hydroxyvomicine ( 8), N-methyl-sec-iso-pseudostrychnine ( 9), sungucine ( 10), isosungucine ( 11), strychnogucine C ( 12), bisnordihydrotoxiferine ( 13), along with the chlorinated indole, N b-chloromethosungucine ( 14).
